title: Police close in on XR protesters forcing them to Trafalgar Square
text:
Protesters remain outside the Home Office (Picture: PA)

Major Extinction Rebellion sites including Westminster Bridge and Smithfield Market have been shut down by police after threatening protesters would be arrested.

The Met has issued a condition imposed under Section 14 of the Public Order Act 1986 ordering that all Extinction Rebellion demonstrations in central London must move to Trafalgar Square.

The condition states: ‘Any assembly linked to the Extinction Rebellion Autumn Uprising who wish to continue with their assembly MUST go to Trafalgar Square and only assemble in the pedestrianised area around Trafalgar Column.’

The Met said the condition does not have a time limit and that it was necessary due to the ‘serious disruption’ protesters were causing to ‘communities in London’.

Right-wing blogger Guido Fawkes claims to have seen a leaked Telegram message sent out to protesters where leaders of the activist group said ‘police removal teams are moving fast’.

The message reveals eight out of 12 of the group’s original protest target sites were still ‘standing’.

Protesters dance to music as they block a street at the bottom of Trafalgar Square (Picture: AP)

Activists outside DEFRA during the second day of climate change demonstrations (Picture: AFP)

Police have warned protesters to move to Trafalgar Square or face arrest (Picture: AFP)

Some chained themselves to a hearse in Trafalgar Square earlier today (Picture: PA)

Among the major sites now cleared of protesters by police were Lambeth Bridge, Westminster Bridge, Smithfield Meat Market and a site on Millbank, Westminster.

In its ‘morning review’, XR told activists about the Millbank site, saying: ‘The North are under a lot of pressure from police, looking like one roadblock about to go.

‘Most tents packed up, arrests occurring and losing infrastructure. Brave and courageous rebels, we love you.’

Those on Lambeth Bridge, where more than 60 people were arrested, have now merged with another protest group, the leaked message said.

Animal Rebellion – who took over Smithfield Market overnight, camping out in tents before replacing meat stalls with fruit and vegetables – have now also moved on from the site, the group said.

According to traffic updates, Westminster Bridge and Victoria Embankment have re-opened – though both have restrictions in place.

Activists from the Animal Rebellion take over Smithfield Meat Market (Picture: AFP)

A pair of protesters chained together at the neck on Westminster Bridge yesterday (Picture: PA)

Police confiscated a giant head on Lambeth bridge on Monday (Picture: AP)

Hundreds of protesters are vowing to camp out for four nights to draw attention to climate change despite being ordered by police to move on or face arrest.

The Met Police said it had arrested 319 people on Monday, easily surpassing the 122 arrests made on the first day of similar protests in the capital in April.

However, Scotland Yard was unable to provide further details on what people were arrested on suspicion of.

The Met said updated arrest figures would be published later.
